Growth Hacking and You

Or The Pro's and Con's of Growth Hacking

April 11, 2017

Growth hacking is a relatively new function of marketing - with the idea initially formulating in 2010 by Sean Ellis, who stated that a growth hacker is "a person whose true north is growth. And everything they do is scrutinized by its impact on scalable growth." The idea behind growth hacking is to do many very rapid experiments across key marketing channels and in the development of products in order to identify the most efficient way to grow a business.

Low-cost marketing tactics, such as social media, viral marketing, and specific targeted advertising is often used. Through this process, many different products can be put to test on the market and what doesn't work is quickly eliminated while what does work grows at an exponential rate, at least that's the idea behind it.

So How Do You Growth Hack

The basic concept of growth hacking is fairly simple, and can be broken down into a few steps, which can then be applied to your products and marketing channels.

  1. Identify and Define your Actionable Goals
  2. Implement analytics and determine Key Performance Idicators to track your goals
  3. Identify your strengths and then leverage them in strategy
  4. Execute your experiment
  5. Optimize the experiement
  6. Rinse and Repeat

After repeated tests, you then use A/B comparison to see what worked, what didn't work, and what can be improved on to make it work. The ideal outcome is to feed into the growth funnel based on your initial actionable goals. The three levels of the funnel are:

  1. Get Visitors
  2. Activate Members
  3. Retain Users

So now that we know a bit more about what growth hacking is and how the ideas of growth hacking are implemented, we need to take a look at the Pro's and Con's of growth hacking.

Pro's and Con's of Growth Hacking

Pro's

  • Rapid experimentation and results - You are able to obtain fairly quick results on your testing, are able to know which avenues to pursue without wasting too much time in pointless tactics
  • Fairly Inexpensive - Compared to traditional marketing outlets, growth hacking can be done without much financial investment, and the approaches taken by growth hacking allows for less commitment to certain marketing avenues.
  • Useable in Most Avenues - Growth hacking can be used fairly easily in just about any type of situation you would need traditional marketing in. Growth hacking is much more favored by start-ups.
  • Knowledge of Audience - While not a direct goal of growth hacking, a person implementing growth hacking strategies tends to discover much more about their targeted audience through the rapid procession of experimentation, leading to more opportunities and avenues to exploit.

Con's

  • Oversaturation of Market - When utilizing growth hacking, in both the marketing and product development aspect, you risk oversaturating the market in terms of new products or new content, thus being counterproductive to growth hacking.
  • Inconsistency - A new company utilizing growth hacking can be seen as inconsistent or not sold on their own products they are trying to sell, Because the experimentation requires a lot of trial and error, your efforts will be temporary until you find what works best, which could lead to mistrust in your particular brand.

Overall, Growth hacking can be incredibly beneficial, especially to new companies and brands, but, to quote the original Spider-Man movie, "With Great Power, Comes Great Responsibiliy." If done properly, growth can be exponential and quick and can and has launched brands effectively, but too much can cripple a new brand before their feet even got off of the ground.
